The introduction of a pyridyl group includes a nitrogen atom, which allows for increased hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, likely contributing an additional +50°C to the melting point. The combination of these groups also adds to the overall symmetry and planar nature of the molecule, which typically increases the melting point further; this effect may add around +30°C. The contributions from the phenyl and pyridyl functional groups are estimated based on typical observed changes they induce in related molecular structures.
